review.title: Outlier Detection using Improved Genetic K-means
review.abstract: The outlier detection problem in some cases is similar to the classification problem. For example, the main concern of clustering-based outlier detection algorithms is to find clusters and outliers, which are often regarded as noise that should be removed in order to make more reliable clustering. In this article, we present an algorithm that provides outlier detection and data clustering simultaneously. The algorithmimprovesthe estimation of centroids of the generative distribution during the process of clustering and outlier discovery. The proposed algorithm consists of two stages. The first stage consists of improved genetic k-means algorithm (IGK) process, while the second stage iteratively removes the vectors which are far from their cluster centroids.

metadata.title: Outlier Detection using Improved Genetic K-means

sections.text: Cluster-based outlier detection algorithms are designed to find clusters and outliers that are often considered noise that should be removed to allow for more reliable clustering. In this article we present an algorithm that provides outlier detection and data clustering at the same time.The algorithm mimics the estimation of generative distribution centroids during the process of clustering and outlier detection. The proposed algorithm consists of two stages. The first stage consists of an improved genetic mean algorithm (IGC), while the second stage iteratively removes vectors that are far from their cluster centers.General Conditions Data Mining.Keywords outlier detection, Genetic algorithms, Clustering, K-mean algorithm, Improved genetic K-mean means (IGC)

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Data mining is generally concerned with the discovery of non-trivial, hidden and interesting knowledge from different types of data. As information technologies evolve, the number of databases, as well as their dimensions and complexity, grows rapidly. It is necessary to automate the analysis of large amounts of data, and the results of the analysis are then used for decision-making by humans or a program. Outliers, on the other hand, are defined as observation that is explained by the underlying probability density function. An outlier is the observation of data that differs so much from other observations that it is suspected that they were generated by a different mechanism from most data [1]. Outliers, on the other hand, are defined as observation that is explained by the underlying probability density function. This function represents the probability distribution of the bulk of data observations [2]. Many data mining algorithms manipulate outliers as a by-product of cluster algorithms. However, these techniques define outliers as points that do not lie in clusters.

sections.heading: 2. IMPROVED GENETIC K-MEANS (IGK)
sections.text: IRTG is an efficient cluster algorithm for handling large amounts of data that can select the initial cluster center using genetic algorithms (GAs), reduce sensitivity to isolated points, avoid the separation of large clusters, and overcome to some extent the data distraction caused by the disproportionate data partitioning due to the introduction of multisampling [5]. The middle steps of the proposed algorithm can be summarized as follows: Algorithm: Improved genetic K agents (S, k), S = {x1, x2,..., xn}. Input: The number of clusters K '(K' > K) and a dataset of n objects xi.Output: A set of k clusters Cj that minimize the square error criterion.

sections.heading: 3. OUTLIER DETECTION METHODS
sections.text: In outlier detection methods based on clusters, outlier detection is defined as an observation that does not fit into the general cluster scheme. [6] The ability to detect outliers can be improved by a combined perspective of outlier detection and clustering. Some outlier algorithms [7-16] treat outliers as special observations, but their main concern is clustering the data set, not detecting outliers. The following techniques have been proposed to detect outliers: Begin 1. Multiple partial samples {S1, Sj}; 2. For m = 1 to j doGenetic K means (Sm, K '); / / Execution Genetic Kmeans, produce K'clusters and j groups.3. Choose min {Jc} as the refined starting points Zj, j [1, K']]; 5. Genetic K means (S, K means.

sections.heading: 4. PROPOSED METHOD
sections.text: Unlike traditional clustering-based methods, the proposed algorithm offers much more efficient outlier detection and data clustering capabilities in the presence of outliers. This approach is based on filtering the data according to the clustering process. The purpose of our method is not only to generate data clusters, but also to find outliers from the resulting clusters. The algorithm of our outlier detection method is divided into two stages. The first step, which is performed using the IGK process and the second stage, is to remove outliers according to a selected threshold. Thus, the proposed method is like the ORC method except in the first stage, ORC was the application of K means. But K means suffer from some drawbacks such as K means being sensitive to the first choice of cluster centers, the clustering method can be very different by starting from different centers, K means cannot handle massive data.

sections.heading: 5. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: We conduct experiments with three synthetic datasets, referred to as A1, A2 and A3 [17], which are shown in Figure 3 and summarized in Table 1 with threshold equal to 0.9 and number of iterations equal to 10, with N being the number of examples and M not representing clusters.Figure 3: Datasets, A1 (left), A2 (center) and A3 (right) The mean square error (MSE), which is used to calculate the difference between the outlier points, was calculated to calculate the error.Figure 4 shows that the error decreases very quickly as the threshold increases, thereby removing more and more objects, reducing the distance between the points and cluster centers.Begin C ← IGK for j ← 1,..., I do / / / I is not an iteration dmax ← maxi | | xi − cpi |} for i, 1..., N > cpi-cpi-2 for the averaged 1.800.SE (1.800.SE).

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we proposed to integrate outlier distance into clustering for non-parametric model estimation.The proposed method was also compared with the standard methods of non-outlier removal of means, and a simple approach was followed in which outlier removal precedes actual cluster building.The proposed method uses both cluster and outlier discovery to improve the estimation of the centroids of generative distribution.The experimental results show that the proposed method can identify outliers more successfully than existing algorithms, indicating that our method has a lower error rate than the competing methods in data sets with overlapping clusters.

sections.heading: 7. ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
sections.text: We would like to express our special thanks to Prof. Adel Abo ElMagd for his encouragement and support during the evaluation.

In Proceedings of the ACM SIGMOD International Conference on Management of Data, vol.30, pp.37-46. [4] Jaing, M., Tseng, S., and Su, C.2001. Two-phase Clustering Process for Outlier Detection.

referenceMentions.context: An outlier is an observation of the data that deviates from other observations so much that it arouses suspicions that it was generated by a different mechanism from the most part of data [1].
This function represents probability distribution of main part of data observations [2].

Another class of techniques defines outliers as points, which are neither a part of a cluster nor a part of the background noise; rather they are specifically points which behave very differently from the norm [3].
It is desirable to identify and remove the outliers, which are far away from all the other points in cluster [4].
So, to improve the clustering such algorithms use the same process and functionality to solve both clustering and outlier discovery [2].

IMPROVED GENETIC K-MEANS (IGK) IGK is an efficient clustering algorithm to handle large scale data, which can select initial clustering center purposefully using Genetic algorithms (GAs), reduce the sensitivity to isolated point, avoid dissevering big cluster, and overcome deflexion of data in some degree that caused by the disproportion in data partitioning owing to adoption of multisampling [5].
OUTLIER DETECTION METHODS In outlier detection methods based on clustering, outlier is defined to be an observation that does not fit to the overall clustering pattern [6].
Some clustering algorithms [7-16] handle outliers as special observations, but their main concern is clustering the dataset, not detecting outliers.
